Reviews.Title: “Cheap and Good”
Reviews.Author: JustineLow
Reviews.Content: This is a budget hotel, it's simple but clean and good. It's very near to a metro station, so it's very convenience. They also provide free Internet connection but a slower speed. However, we didn't find it slow at all. Overall we are happy with our stay there and the staffs are very helpful too. Only if possible, avoid room 403 because the wooden floor crack everytime you walk around the room, hope they get it repaired by now.

Reviews.Title: “Good option to see Madrid on a budget”
Reviews.Author: Dave_Saunders
Reviews.Content: This is our fourth Ibis hotel in the past year and this hotel embodies what we have come to expect: good service; a friendly english speaking staff; clean rooms; good metro access. We found that this hotel had all of these. The hotel is a short 200 meter walk from the metro and has a nice bar/restaurant available. We found the rooms to be normal Ibis rooms; small sparsely furnished rooms but totally adequate for two people or even a couple with a small child. We had numerous questions for the staff regarding the metro, train, etc. and they were extremely helpful. We would stay here again and would recommend this Ibis to anyone travelling to Madrid on a tight budget.

Reviews.Title: “Update to Reviews of December 2007 and March 2011”
Reviews.Author: Chelydra
Reviews.Content: My partner and I stayed again at this Ibis at the beginning of April 2012. The details of my previous reviews still apply but with the following observations. Reception staff were pleasant, cooperative, helpful and responsive. We had our preferred room on the top floor facing the back and farthest from the lift-elevator. Unfortunately, a large air conditioning unit on the top of a building opposite operated between about 6-7 a.m. and the noise entered the room. The hotel gave us another room facing the front, but this admitted some street noise. If you can run the air conditioning unit, the three-speed fan covers these minor outside noises. Unfortunately, the system was set for winter, that is, heating only from November to March, inclusive. (The hotel system is changed at some point to cooling over summer, April to October, inclusive.) Thus, during our stay we could have heating only (which was unneeded at the time) either on or off. There was no option for simple ventilation, that is, room air circulation without either heating or cooling. The thermostat dial, marked in degrees centigrade, had no discernable effect regardless of the temperature we selected. This meant that, if the room became too hot, the only feasible option was to open the window. The practicality of this choice depended on one's sensitivity to and the volume of outside noises. If you might be easily disturbed by outside noise, try to get a room as high up as possible and facing away from street activities. Should you take a taxi to Barajas airport, consult reception and have the driver agree on the route before you leave the hotel — or you might be taken on a longer ride than necessary so that the driver can increase the tariff. (This also happened to us in Lisbon; the driver contemptuously ignored the map I gave him showing the route I wanted him to take.) The airport is a short drive from the hotel, and easily reached by going along Calle de Acala (at the top of Calle de Valentin Beato) — which reaches and then parallels Avenida de America — to Autovia M-22 and Autovia de Acceso al Aeropuerto de Barajas (or the airport service road which parallels them). If the taxi driver proceeds down Calle de Valentin Beato away from Calle de Acala, turns left at the end into Calle de Albasanz and proceeds along various roads till you see a stadium (Estadio La Peineta) in the distance to your left, you will know that he is taking a longer route than necessary. Compared to taking the train and then the bus, the short taxi trip is expensive: in addition to the meter charge for the actual trip, before you get into the vehicle there is an initial charge of 6.35 euros plus 5 euros airport charge for each passenger when you arrive at the airport terminal. In all, the fare for our brief, circuitous trip, with almost no other traffic as it was early morning, came to 24.95 euros (about $33). If you can manage your luggage using public transport, use the metro to Canillejas and then the 200 bus to the airport. With advance reservation, car rental for a day could cost less than a taxi fare. Street parking during the workday remains impractical because of the commercial activities in the surrounding area. Parking on the hotel property is 7 euros per night. Also, the hotel charges 5 euros per day for use of WiFi room Internet; however, the first 20 minutes use of the hotel computer in the lobby are free. It really is time that the entire Ibis chain has its room tariffs include WiFi Internet service at no extra charge, as do other hotel chains.

Reviews.Title: “nice location”
Reviews.Author: teote
Reviews.Content: According to the Ibis standarts. I advice this hotel because; -Free parking in street or paid secured parking available -If with car or not, no problem. Because metro station is just 100 meter away. Park car in hotel, go to centre by metro. Good for the price.

Reviews.Title: “Standard IBIS with bigger than usual showers.”
Reviews.Author: retiredvacationers
Reviews.Content: We tend to give IBIS hotels 3 star ratings as they are good average hotels. This one had some advantages over other IBIS we have stayed in. The most noticable advantage was the big shower - big enough for 2, and bathroom. The room size was slightly bigger than some. Beds, breakfast etc all standard. There is an ETAP hotel backing on to this IBIS that charges about 2/3rd the IBIS rate So bear this in mind if youre on a tight budget. Even though in a suburban location it takes just over 15 minutes on the metro to Gran Via. To get to "Sol" means changing trains so its better to walk above ground from a green line station. Buy a TEN journey ticket or tourist pass to save money on the metro.

Reviews.Title: “cheap and clean”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: I stayed for 2 nights in end Jan12. The hotel was clean, cheap with a very simple design. It's very closed to metro station suanzes. The taxi fare from hotel to airport is EUR25 and about 15-20 mins ride.I didn't walk around hotel as I had limited time in Madrid. I don't mind staying in this hotel again in the future. If you are looking for a hotel very close to the city, this hotel is not for you.

Reviews.Title: “Not bad”
Reviews.Author: FeasgarMath
Reviews.Content: Pretty standard Ibis, rooms fine although mine had a spare bed instead of a table which was okay as only a short overnight stay but could have been annoying. Wifi not well advertised, nothing in room and no way to pay via computer or tv - I presume you had to go to reception. Restaurant in evening decent and breakfast good.

Reviews.Title: “Standard Ibis”
Reviews.Author: majek89
Reviews.Content: I stayed in a lot of Ibis hotels and they look more or less the same. This one was not different. Room was quite clean. Service was ok and nice. Wi-Fi was payable (5 EUR/day). You can also use it for 15 minutes free in their computer on the 1st floor. Breakfast was delicious and varied. Hotel is located near the metro station (c.a. 3-5 minutes on foot). Station is called Suanzes (line 5). I recommend this hotel to everyone.

Reviews.Title: “Small Rooms”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: I have been staying at accorhotels for a long time but this ibis must have the smallest rooms of all. We felt being in the cage rather than a room. There was no tea or coffee making facilities in the room. I will definately not be staying at this hotel in the future purely because of the size of the rooms.

Reviews.Title: “Madrid, Madrid, Madrid !”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: A very nice and comfortable stay in one of the most wonderful cities of the world. The rooms are small but the bed is huge ! As we stayed four nights we would have needed better place for the luggage, but we found place under the bed. The staff was very friendly and professional. This IBIS hotel is well worth the price !

Reviews.Title: “What you would expect from an IBIS hotel, excellent for Spain”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: I have stayed several times in this hotel and I can confirm that it is the best value in Madrid. The location is excellent if you are attending a show in Madrid Fair (Ifema) and is conveniently located to access the center of the city and close to the main routes around Madrid (M3 and M4). The staff is always friendly, and helpful. When it is busy you might find something lacking in your room, but when you complain they immediately act on it. Wireless Internet is acceptable in terms of speed. Breakfast was better before. Now is basic (reduction costs, I imagine) but still what you need. I will stay there again.

Reviews.Title: “Good quality hotel”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: I stay in Ibis hotels all over Europe and the Madrid hotel was a s good as the others. You can get to the hotel from the airport in 30 minutes by a combination of airport bus and the Metro. The area the hotel is in, is quiet, there is a nearby park you can have a walk in and a few good Italian restuarants by the hotel on the main road. Takes about 10 - 20 minutes to get to the centre of Madrid from the hotel by Metro. Good quality breakfast, clean rooms, good air conditioning, International channels on the TV (including Sky News for all the UK readers of this review), good sized bathroom and also a left luggage room. Friendly staff. Would stay at this hotel again the next time I visit Madrid.

Reviews.Title: “Exactly what you expect from Ibis”
Reviews.Author: sensor30
Reviews.Content: The hotel is simple and what we liked the most was cleanliness. The bathroom was impeccable clean, so was the room. Very comfortable mattress. A minus for the air conditioning, which is not very efficient at night, and the Madrid nights are quite hot in end June. Too many local TV channels compared to international ones. We like to see some global news at the end of the day and the management of the hotel has more to work on that. The breakfast was satisfactory, somehow lacking the vegetables (was it because we were in the middle of the E. Coli epidemic scandal or is the usual?) The coffee is undrinkable, but after the Barcelona experience I began to think this is a general situation all over Spain. The location of the hotel is good, surrounded by almost empty office buildings, car dealers with no customers, a large park nearby and a metro station that will get you to city center in 15 minutes. Best access to/from airport is by taxi as it will cost just 10-12 euros and will take only 10 minutes. The staff at the reception speak English and was helpful in providing us with free city and metro maps and pointed on these the main tourist attractions. Tourist reccomendations for Madrid: Prado Museum: allow at least a full day. Most impressed by the paintings: "Dead Christ Supported by an Angel" by Antonello da Messina, " Annunciation " by Fra Angelico and the dark period of Goya. Las Ventas: must see a bull fight if you are not a hypocrite who claims animal rights and have a large steak for dinner. The matadors are brave, elegant and risk their life every second. Royal Palace: royal armory Escorial trip: closed on Monday Toledo trip: allow at least 1 1/2 hours to buy the train tickets at Atocha Station. Long waiting rows, few vendors and no machine vending tickets. It is stupid to wait 2 hours to get the tickets for a one hour trip! A general complaint for Madrid: there is a no photo, no video policy in all museums, even without flash - unique stupidity all around Europe.

Reviews.Title: “The best staff”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: The hotel is a little far from the city centre, but the metro station is 200m from the hotel, very good signed, also the bus stop to go to the large shopping centre.The rooms are small, but very clean. You can get various things for breakfast. The best of the hotel is the hotel staff: very friendly and helpful: ask them anything and you got a good answer: where to go to see things, where to go to eat, where the best shopping centre is ...... I will come back for sure.....

Reviews.Title: “Great Ibis Hotel”
Reviews.Author: anvarao
Reviews.Content: Great Hotel... Propably the best Ibis I've ever stayed! Very clean, nice staff and very quiet. The room is a little bigger than the standar Ibis. Just 2 minutes away from Suanzes metro station with direct line to city center (15-20 minutes ride).

Reviews.Title: “Good hotel”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: Nice hotel with IBis standards. We've been to other Ibis hotels in Europe and this was the best, the room was a little bigger than other hotel rooms in Europe, which are usually small. This hotel is located a little far from town center but is located 5 minutes away from a metro station and from there is a 20 minute train ride to the center and worked perfectly for us. Taxi to the airport was 15 euros. Service was good enough, but the hotel is very recommendable. Madrid is pretty safe but try to avoid walking around this neighborhood late at night.

Reviews.Title: “Ibis Madrid Valentin Beato”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: The hotel was easy to find and is close to metro station.This made it easy to go into the centre of Madrid. The staff were friendly and eager to help. They explained which stops were best to use, to see different parts of the city. We used the restaurant twice and enjoyed the meal each time. The room was clean, bed was comfortable.

Reviews.Title: “Update to Review of December 2007”
Reviews.Author: Chelydra
Reviews.Content: My partner and I stayed again at this Ibis at the end of March 2011. The details of my previous review still apply but with the following changes. The conduct of the staff at reception has improved. Fabrizio O. who checked us in was exceptionally pleasant, helpful and cooperative, and also his colleague Ana. He assigned to us exactly the type of room that we prefer and obtained information and travel directions to a particular location that we had wanted to visit. The hotel restaurant had a E13.75 fixed-price menu (we did not eat there). This consists of one appetizer or one dessert, one dish of the day and one drink from a choice of mineral water or a class of wine or a beer or a soft drink. For the price, you can do better elsewhere with a "menu del dia" which can have a lower price and give you more choice and quantity. The E6.50 fixed-price breakfast buffet was available from 6:30 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. (with a simpler breakfast available earlier than the buffet). The air conditioning was set for winter, that is, heating only from November to April, inclusive. (The hotel system is changed to cooling over summer, May to October, inclusive.) Thus, during our stay we could have heating only — which was unneeded at the time — either on or off. There was no option for simple ventilation, that is, room air circulation without either heating or cooling. The thermostat dial, marked in degrees centigrade, had no discernable effect regardless of the temperature we selected. This meant that, if the room became to hot, the only feasible option was to open the window. Quieter rooms are at the back facing away from the front of the hotel and the street. Covered parking on the hotel property costs E7 per night, but you can find free street parking. Since the hotel is in a commercial area with car sales, maintenance and repair shops and offices, parking space outside business hours is quite easy to find but much less so when all the offices and shops are open and fully operating. The number 200 bus serves all four terminals of the Madrid Barajas airport. Now when you get off at the bus stop for Canillejas metro station (and go to Suanzes station a short walk to the Ibis), you can cross the street directly at two sets of traffic lights to get to the entrance to the station. (You no longer have to take the pedestrian bridge to get across.) The 200 bus from Canillejas going to the airport leaves from the bus shelters at the far edge of the open bus plaza. Note that the mezzanine (middle) level of the metro station provides direct access to the bus plaza. The top-level exit comes out across the street from the bus plaza. A bus-train ticket with ten trips now costs E9.30 (appealing more for convenience than great savings). There is still an additional E1 supplement because the airport is in the next fare zone. Note that there is no transfer facility between the two modes of transport, so a trip between the hotel and airport currently costs E3 (E1 for the bus, E1 for the metro and E1 for the supplement). Tickets are available from multilingual touch-screen vending machines in the basement (-1 level) of the terminal. The bus leaves from (and arrives at) the ground (0 level). You can buy Abono Turistico tickets for 1, 2, 3, 5 and 7 days of unlimited travel over zones A (Madrid city area) and T (regional beyond the city). If you expect to use public transport extensively for sightseeing, these tickets are worth considering. From the hotel you can easily get to a centro comercial with a Carrefour at Avenida de Guadalajara 2. (The building had a sign saying that Carrefour was open 24 hours a day; however, you might want to check. especially on Sundays. Usually Carrefours are open from 10 a.m. to 10 p.m., closed on Sundays.) Take the metro to Ventas station and change to Line 2 which now finishes not La Elipa but at Las Rosas (one of four new stations at the time of writing this, so they will not appear on metro maps earlier than Marzo 2011/2). Get off at Alsacia station and the centro is across the street from the exit. It also has a McDonalds with free WiFi. The VIP restaurant at the centro also has free WiFi. The restaurant El Castillio on Calle Augusto Figueroa 8 that I suggested in my December 2011 review has, unfortunately, closed (a pity as the couple who ran it served simple but good regional home cooking). As alternatives I suggest your trying nearby Vivares at Calle Hortaleza 37 (there is another Vivares across the street at 52). They have fixed-price menus (E9.60, E11.90 and E12.90, depending on the dishes offered) for complete meals with a choice of beverage included (two people can share a 750 ml bottle of wine). The service was good and the food reasonable in quality, quantity and presentation. If you are near Plaza Calao, Topolino at Plaza Santo Domingo offers a E8.90 buffet, excluding beverages. The choice and quality of the food was supposedly Italian but reasonable all things considered. On a lane, Calle de Caballero de Gracia, just off the Gran Via metro station at the top of Calle de la Montera leading to Plaza Sol, there is a Chinese buffet and near it a Fres Co buffet.

Reviews.Title: “good”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: We had a difficulty finding the hotel and when we finally found it we hadn't realized that one of the rooms (I booked 2 rooms)only had one bed. The two ladies that were sharing the room did not want to share a bed. The hotel acommodated us the next day by moving he ladies to another room,

Reviews.Title: “Clean, comfortable and cheap”
Reviews.Author: annabanannaMelbourne
Reviews.Content: We stayed one night at the Ibis Valentin Beato. It is located 10 mins from the airport, and 200 metres from the Suanzes Metro station. You can get to the Plaza Mayor on the metro in about 15 mins. Metro tickets in Madrid are only 1 euro. Reception staff were friendly. The room was of the usual Ibis standard, nothing grand, but very clean. No safe provided. Bed was very comfortable, and the room was quiet at night. Buffet breakfast was 6.50 euros, and was good value, with cold meats, bread, churros, juices and coffee. If you don't mind catching the metro into the city, this is a good value place to stay. Not many cafes or restaurants in the local area, but there is a supermarket about 400 metres walk away. Overall, if you book early and get a good rate, I would recommend this hotel. We also stayed in the Etap Hotel which is in the street directly behind this hotel. Room rates are even cheaper there.

Reviews.Title: “Ibis is Ibis”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: This Ibis is like other Ibis: very good and very good value. Except the expensive internet access! Its quite and the metro is really near. The breakfast is basic, we only did it one time. Good personal. Good elavator. Good beds.

Reviews.Title: “Excellent value”
Reviews.Author: BetsyHK
Reviews.Content: Comfortable hotel with welcoming staff. We stayed three nights with our group of high school students and the staff was great. The rooms were small, but comfortable and clean. The breakfast buffet was varied and delicious. The hotel is close to a Metro station outside the center of town.

Reviews.Title: “Good value and services”
Reviews.Author: Posted by an Accorhotels.com traveler
Reviews.Content: A little bit far from the city center but Near Metro station. A supermarket is in walking distance. Good prices and nice,helpful staff.

Reviews.Title: “IBIS standard”
Reviews.Author: coa3
Reviews.Content: Like other IBIS. Easy, Clean, Simple. There is parking, but it is possible to park on the street. During the day is difficult, but not overnight. Is one block from the subway station Suanzes.

Reviews.Title: “Great value”
Reviews.Author: aepooliveira
Reviews.Content: This Ibis hotel is the best choice if you are looking for something with great price, great staff, good rooms and breakfest. The staff and breakfest were the differential, very polity, avaliable and kind. Great place to stay if you don't mind using metro.

Reviews.Title: “Fine, but not up to usual Ibis standard”
Reviews.Author: New_Malden_flier
Reviews.Content: So, the good stuff - usual decent Ibis deal, room OK, staff friendly, clean, comfortable, TV has Sky, wifi only 5 euros for 24 hours. Excellent location, Metro on the corner, 15min to the airport, 15min to downtown. And you can park on the street - which is wonderful in Madrid. But restaurant was hopelessly overcrowded for breakfast and dinner on my first day due to huge party of Russian tourists. I was told to come back for dinner in 20 minutes. More bizarrely, there has been no white wine of any kind, and no rioja either, in what is actually a French hotel in the capital of Spain, for two days. Ludicrous. So not quite what I've come to expect of Ibis or Accor.

Reviews.Title: “Decent base for Madrid weekend”
Reviews.Author: MurrayfieldMan
Reviews.Content: It's an Ibis: so the room was pretty much like any other - comfortable bed, basic storage, good shower room - clean and functional. The staff were helpful - provided a map and wifi access (cheap - €3 for 24 hours if I remember correctly). We arrived late and ate a bar snack at midnight - very pleasant. The breakfast buffet was good, and typical of decent Spanish hotels - good choice of meats, cheese and breads with proper filter coffee. It's within about 100 metres of a metro stop, in a decent area to the NE of the city centre - about 30 minutes from Atocha RENFE and a 15/20 minute taxi ride from the airport. We used it for the first night of an InterRail trip and the room was ideal as it had plenty of space/surfaces for repacking rucsacs!

Reviews.Title: “Good service , neat accom and nice area”
Reviews.Author: joris_de_groote
Reviews.Content: Positive: Staff were very friendly ; hotel had neat rooms and in the bar a bottle of water costs just 1.7 euro . A good airco as well it helped us out during the warm nights. Suanzes metro station is just around the corner. 12 minutes from the city center ... no real item ( safety & & & )

Reviews.Title: “Pleasant...”
Reviews.Author: shilpv
Reviews.Content: I stayed there with 2 other friends. The hotel, though a bit far from the city center, is well connected via the metro. The staff is helpful and the neighborhood is peaceful.

Reviews.Title: “Modern and confortable”
Reviews.Author: nunisafe
Reviews.Content: This is a very modern and comfortable hotel. The rooms are very clean though they are small. It is not in the center of Madrid but It is located near a subway station. If you travel by car it is ideal because there is plenty of parking place in the streets in that area. The breakfast is OK but the restaurant is very bad. Bar and restaurant Staff as difficulty in speaking foreign languages. The hotel was crowded with young people so it was not calm, as you can imagine. After all, it is a very good hotel, with a good quality-price relation and well located for my necessities.

Reviews.Title: “Very nice hotel, a little way out of town”
Reviews.Author: franko81
Reviews.Content: Very nice hotel, great room, very modern amenities. The hotel was a bit far out of town but the tube was just up the road and quite cheap.

Reviews.Title: “What else do you expect?”
Reviews.Author: jeanpereira
Reviews.Content: The best thing about Ibis hotels is that you get exactly what you expect. There's never a surprise. Friendly and english-speaking staff, clean roons, near subway, etc. I will always return to an Ibis, they never disappoint you.

Reviews.Title: “A good night sleep”
Reviews.Author: tuga21
Reviews.Content: It was our first time at a Ibis Hotel and we were very pleased. The rooms aren't very big, but they are modern and comfortable. The downside is, they don't have a safe in the room or minibar. The subway station is not far, and there's a convenience store at about 150 meters from it.(Calle de Alcalá nº494). We decided to have breakfast in the downtown area. There are several places to chose from around Grand via, and Plaza de la Puerta de Sol. Overall it was a very good experience, considering that we paid 98€ for two nights, couldn't expect much more.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: allnamesbloodytaken
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I went to Spain for a little longer than a week and stayed at Ibis.We liked the rooms's layout,all very practical.We had a clean room with the basic amenities (tv,phone,etc).You must keep an eye on your phone bill though as the price they publish on Reception are 100% misleading when it comes to phone calls cost per minute.I paid nearly 120 € for 4 phone calls or so and for not longer then 3 minutes each!..The staff is very friendly and helpful at all times.Hotel's location is far from city centre and Chueca (nevermind,Madrid has very efficient public transport system running until 01:30,if you missed that one then you can still fall back on the night buses running till 6:30 app.) but close to the airport if you are driving a car.Suanzes metro station (line 5 "green") also near the hotel on Alcala street wich is also plenty of restaurant serving italian,chinese and local food.

Reviews.Title: “Modern, clean, contemporary hotel with restaurant-bar; very near Suanzes station”
Reviews.Author: Chelydra
Reviews.Content: Convenient to Madrid center and to the airport, the hotel is located in a commercial-industrial area. Car repair shops line the street, so that during business hours it has lots of parked vehicles; outside business hours you will find the area deserted. The newspaper El Pais has production facilities at the far end of the street. The few restaurants in the general area seem to function according to the opening hours of local businesses (otherwise, no customers). We chose this hotel for its convenience to Suanzes metro station and its reasonable price (given the current decline of the U.S. dollar). We would probably return to stay again. The station provides easy access to central Madrid (15-20 minutes) and to Terminals 1, 2 and 3 of Barajas airport (30-35 minutes). The five-story hotel (with pay parking) lies a very brief walk up the street from the station (1-2 minutes). It provides a base for going out sightseeing rather than a place to vacation in itself. If you take the metro to Suanzes, as you approach the doors which access stairs to the street leave from the side where the sign says “Pares”; otherwise, you will emerge on the side of the main street with a large park. Valentin Beato is at the nearby corner at the side of a Land Rover dealership; walk toward the “P” sign in the distance, as the hotel sits back from the street. We found the hotel desk staff polite, efficient and cooperative — but business-like. On all the occasions we encountered, at least one staff member spoke English or French. Internet connection using the hotel’s desktop computer in the lobby or your laptop costs, as do phone calls. The small, cramped lounge area near the hotel entrance has a rack with current Spanish newspapers. The rooms have light-wood, built-in contemporary furniture, platform beds and parquet wood floors (for ease of cleaning). Yes, you can hear footsteps from adjoining rooms; however, the limited free floor space means that you will most likely hear a cleaner servicing a room in the morning rather than another guest at night. (It would help us jet-lagged and late risers if the cleaning staff wore soft-soled slippers as they went about their work; better still, Accor should carpet the rooms.) The modern, spacious bathroom provided a shower (but not a bathtub), liquid soap exclusively, two towels and a bath mat. The room had a heavy, solid door which closed tightly onto its frame, which ran across the floor as well, and had a surrounding rubber seal. (I wish that U.S. hotels standardized on this type of door and frame.) Coupled with carpeting in the corridor, we did not hear any noise from outside the door. The top, fourth floor, has the quietest rooms because you will not have anyone above. You might want to avoid rooms nearest the elevator; also, the cleaners have their trolleys and supplies in a room to the side. Room 420 at one end of the corridor faces away from the street; room 421 opposite it faces the street. Room 431 at the other end of the corridor faces away from the street; room 430 opposite it faces the street. These last two rooms have a separate door at the end of the corridor which isolates them even further, and serves to make them equivalent to adjoining rooms for a family. If you arrive at Terminal T1, after passing through passport control and customs go to the tourist information kiosk. Obtain street and metro maps and information on museums, art galleries, shopping and the like. We encountered a pleasant woman who spoke English and provided useful literature from the shelves to which only she had access. Madrid has a superb metro and bus system — modern, comprehensive, frequent, safe, clean and operating till late. Check whether you have an up-to-date metro map, as lots of them still in circulation omit new stations along extended lines. For instance, Line 5, green, serving Suanzes station and thus the hotel, now ends at Alameda de Osuna (near the airport) not at Canillejas (construction of its extension continues and it will probably reach the station at Terminal 2 at some point in the near future). Line 10, dark blue, now ends at Hospital del Norte not at Herrera Oria. Using the moving footways, walk to Terminal T2 which has the metro station. (Note that walking to the metro station in T2 and then finding the bus stop might take a bit of wandering around. If you need to, ask for directions at any information counter; usually someone speaks English.) From a vending machine with a touch screen, buy a “Bono de 10 Viajes” (10-trip ticket) for 6.40 euros (at the time of writing). Note that from and to the airport you have to pay a 1 euro supplement per person, as the airport terminals lie in the next fare zone. The machine also has a touch-screen button for the supplement. Go outside to the bus stop across the road for the Linea 200 bus and take it to Canillejas. (On a bus and in a metro station, you feed the ticket into a lower slot on a reader and retrieve it from an upper slot. Several people can use the same ticket as long as each person passes it through the machine reader.) The bus has racks for luggage. Check that the visual display announcing the next stop works, and press one of the buttons near the exit door in the middle of the bus to request the stop; otherwise, the driver will speed by. If the display does not work, ensure that the driver knows clearly that you want to get off at Canillejas. When you alight from the bus, cross over the road to Canillejas metro station using the pedestrian footbridge over the highway. Lonely Planet and Time Out have the best guides to Madrid in English. Buy before you leave home, as you will pay more for them in Spain. Also, from a Madrid newsagent buy a Guia del Ocio (a weekly) and a copy of El Pais (a daily) to check the hours of opening (or if open at all) of places you would like to visit. Every publication we referred to had something incorrect.

Reviews.Title: “very good hotel”
Reviews.Author: touchet
Reviews.Content: I stayed just one night in hotel Ibis Valentin Beato.The Hotel is new , the room is excellent, isn´t too big, but it´s OK. The beds, the mattress and the blankets are very good. The cleaning is quite good. The breakfast is sufficient, but there isn´t great variety of food. The hotel is near metro station - Suanzes - but in surroundings to the hotel there is practically nothing. In conclusion, the hotel is very good and is a excellent choice for the one who goes to madrid and the price is good too.

Reviews.Title: “Much better than expected!”
Reviews.Author: SiZ
Reviews.Content: I chose Ibis mainly due to the fact that with the low price, I thought I knew what to expect from an Ibis. Well, it wasn't really the case -- as it surpassed my expectation! The room was basic, however seemed to be very new, had a contemporary feel and very clean. The location, while not exactly in the middle of the city, was only 2 min walk from a metro station (Suanzes, green line #5) which goes directly to the heart of the city (approx. 15 min to Sol, Opera, Gran Via, etc). If coming from the airport, take bus #204 from in front of T4 terminal to Canillejas (2 stops from airport), and from there take the metro (2 stops) to Suanzes. The trip (airport to hotel) takes approx. 20 min. The only problem we had was the noise from the other room(s) -- we could hear the sound of the water from the shower and footsteps -- however, it wasn't at all a problem for us, as it wasn't loud.
